title-group.article-title: A Timing Strategy for Investments in U.S. Hospitality Stocks

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2012 International Council on Hotel, Restaurant and Institutional Education

abstract.p: Historical data for the period from January 2, 1973 to May 30, 2008 show that U.S. airline, hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure sector indices underperformed the market portfolio (S&P 500) in terms of the Sharpe ratio. This result suggests that simply buying and holding hospitality sector stocks is a poor investment strategy. It is necessary for hospitality stock investors to find a method of improving their investments in U.S. hospitality sector stocks. This study offers a timing strategy for investing in U.S. hospitality sector stocks. Directional changes in the Fed discount rate signal when to buy or sell stocks of different hospitality sectors. Accordingly, a timing strategy is formulated and its performance relative to a passive buy-and-hold (market portfolio) strategy is examined with five risk-adjusted performance measures. Empirical evidence derived from the daily trading data over a 35-year period generally supports the superiority of the proposed timing strategy for investments in hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure sector stocks over the buy-and-hold strategy based on various risk-adjusted performance evaluation methods.

body.p: Empirical research shows that monetary policy has a significant impact on security returns. Jensen and Johnson (1995), Jensen, Mercer, and Johnson (1996), Patelis (1997), Thorbecke (1997), Conover, Jensen, and Johnson (1999a, 1999b), Mann, Atra, and Dowen (2004), Bernanke and Kuttner (2005), and Conover, Jensen, Johnson, and Mercer (2005, 2008) find that U.S. stock returns are significantly related to changes in Federal Reserve (Fed) monetary policy. Their studies reveal that stock returns are higher during periods following an expansive policy and lower following the introduction of a restrictive policy.

Previous studies also suggest that certain monetary policy indicators, such as money supply, discount rate change, and reserve aggregates, have the ability to explain stock performance and can be used as an investment strategy (Jensen & Johnson, 1995; Patelis, 1997; Smirlock & Yawitz, 1985; Thorbecke, 1997; Waud, 1970). Indeed, more and more investors keep a close eye on the monetary policy conducted by the Fed and often base their investment strategies on observed monetary indicators. As a result, Fed monetary policy has attracted attention from stock investors and “Fed watching” has been a prevalent strategy in investment management (Johnson & Jensen, 1998).

Monetary policy has a critical role in the performance of hospitality stocks for the following reasons. First, Nowak (1993) argues that monetary policy changes are likely to have a strong impact on industries that are sensitive to interest rates. The hospitality industry, such as airline and hotel, is capital-intensive, and requires regular and large investment decisions (Collier & Gregory, 1995); it is thus sensitive to changes in the interest rate. Second, as Singh and Kwansa (1999) note, experts from the lodging and financial services industries assert that the monetary policy would be one of the key factors that have a profound influence on the lending criteria and terms by financial institutions holding hotel mortgages. Therefore, changes in monetary policy can significantly affect hotel stock performance because the lending criteria and terms can affect hotel firms’ ability to access capital.

A significant impact of the changes in monetary policy on hospitality stock performance has also been documented in the hospitality finance literature. Barrows and Naka (1994) show that growth rates of money supply could serve as an important explanatory factor of U.S. hospitality stock returns. Chen, Kim, and Kim (2005) reveal that money supply growth rates have a significantly positive impact on Taiwanese hotel stock returns. Chen (2007c) finds that time lag changes in the discount rate have a significantly negative influence on Chinese hotel stock returns. Chen (2007a) uses changes in the discount rate to measure shifts in monetary policy regimes and detects that hotel stocks in Taiwan perform better under an expansive monetary condition in terms of a higher mean return and reward-to-risk ratio, supporting that shifts in monetary policy stances measured by changes in the discount rate can significantly affect hotel stock returns.

Although Barrows and Naka (1994), Chen et al. (2005), and Chen (2007a, 2007c) verify that hospitality stock returns are significantly linked to certain economic and monetary variables, they are silent on one important and practical question: How can investors who invest in hospitality stocks benefit from their studies? In other words, although the predictive ability of economic or monetary variables to stock price behavior in the hospitality industry has been identified, there is still insufficient information to guide investors’ investment decision in hospitality stocks.

For instance, U.S. hospitality stock returns can be explained by three fundamental economic variables: growth rates in the money supply, changes in domestic consumption, and the expected inflation rate (Barrows & Naka, 1994). The problem with such findings for hospitality stock investors is that three economic series need to be followed and interpreted. There is a strong possibility that those economic factors may present conflicting signals. It hence complicates the investment process for hospitality stock investors by attempting to weight the contribution of several factors to future U.S. hospitality stock returns.

This study contributes to the hospitality literature by offering a timing strategy for investments in U.S. hospitality sector stocks. The timing investment strategy has been a popular research topic in the finance literature (Chang & Lewellwn, 1984; Goetzmann, Ingersoll, & Ivkovic, 2000; Henriksson & Merton, 1981; Lehmann & Modest, 1987; Sharpe, 1966; Shilling, 1992; Tezel & McManus, 2001; Treynor, 1965). Nonetheless, within the hospitality finance literature, no work offers a timing strategy to investors who are interested in hospitality stocks. In particular, Henriksson and Merton (1981) and Chang and Lewellwn (1984) show that mutual fund managers are unable to time the market successfully. This study provides hospitality stock investors with a simple trading rule based on changes in the Fed discount rate and illustrates that the proposed investment strategy can successfully time the market.

According to the proposed timing trading rule, an investment structure with only two assets is assumed (i.e., a diversified portfolio consisting of hospitality sector stocks and Treasury bills). Shifts in the discount rate implemented by the Fed are used to classify the monetary policy environment as either restrictive or expansive. An expansive monetary environment is characterized by a decrease in the discount rate, whereas a restrictive monetary environment is associated with an increase in the discount rate. Different monetary environments accordingly serve as a signal to buy or sell hospitality sector stocks and investors in hospitality stocks can allocate their portfolios between hospitality sector stocks and Treasury bills (T-bills) based on different monetary policy environments. This timing strategy, based on directional changes in the Fed discount rate, hence offers hospitality stock investors clear signals to hold hospitality sector stocks during expansive monetary periods and invest in T-bills during restrictive monetary periods.

The rest of the article is organized as follows. Related studies are reviewed in the next section. Sample data and the proposed timing strategy are addressed in the subsequent section. The risk-adjusted performance evaluation methods are introduced next. The penultimate section presents results of the performance evaluation according to the proposed timing strategy. The final section concludes the study with discussions of its major findings.

sec.title: Related Studies
sec.p: Market timing is a popular investment strategy among stock market investors and mutual funds managers. In practice, market timing involves asset class reallocation based on active investment techniques that seek to outperform the market by shifting funds to different asset classes. A market-timing strategy in the finance literature generally proposes that a diversified stock portfolio and a risk-free asset (T-bills) are available for investment, and investors should hold stocks during bull markets and T-bills during bear markets. Based on such an actively managed investment strategy, investors are expected to achieve a better investment performance than they would if they followed a passive buy-and-hold market portfolio strategy.

Nonetheless, empirical results from previous market timing literature have not been conclusive. Chang and Lewellen (1984), Cumby and Glen (1990), Grinblatt and Titman (1994), Malkiel (1995), Daniel et al. (1997), Kao, Cheng, and Chan (1998), Becker, Ferson, Myers, and Schill (1999), and Goetzmann et al. (2000) find little evidence in support of the market timing skills. In contrast, Lehmann and Modest (1987), Lee and Rahman (1990), Weigel (1991), Larsen and Wozniak (1995), Ferson and Schadt (1996), Bello and Janjigian (1997), Prather and Bertin (1998), Tezel and McManus (2001), and Conover et al. (2008) have obtained evidence in favor of market timing ability. Tezel and McManus (2001) argue that the lack of strong results in support of the market timing ability may be because of the fact that few mutual funds managers specialize in market timing.

In spite of the contradictory empirical findings noted above regarding the merit of market timing, many studies provide consistent evidence that changes in monetary policy can significantly affect stock returns. Jensen and Johnson (1995), Jensen et al. (1996), Conover et al. (1999b), Conover et al. (2005), and Jensen and Mercer (2006) have shown that U.S. security returns are closely related to changes in Fed discount rate. The theoretical link between stock price and Fed discount rate can be described as follows.
The stock price, according to the dividend discount model, equals the present value of all expected future dividend payments into perpetuity:

Equation (2) reveals that a shift in monetary policy can influence stock performance in two ways.

First, changes in the Fed discount rate can exhibit an indirect impact on stock prices by altering expected future cash flows (earnings and dividend payments). The Fed sets monetary policy by regulating interest rates, which in turn, affect a firm’s cost of capital and the national economy. The Fed can implement an expansive monetary policy by reducing the discount rate. In contrast, the Fed can lift the discount rate and raise the interest rate to implement a restrictive monetary policy. Thus, shifts in the Fed discount rate signal the future direction of the economy and offer useful information about potential economic climate and corporate earnings. Accordingly, an expansive (restrictive) monetary policy is expected to increase (decrease) the overall level of economic activity and generate higher (lower) cash flows in the future, and the stock price then responds in a positive (negative) manner.

Second, a change in the discount rate used by market participants can have a direct impact on stock prices. As mentioned, changes in monetary policy can signal the movements of the market rates of interest and consequently affect the discount factors used by market participants. For instance, tighter monetary policy leads to a rise in the rate at which firms’ future cash flows are capitalized and in turn deteriorates stock prices. Alternatively, monetary policy easing is associated with lower interest rate and can raise stock prices.

Accordingly, Jensen et al. (1996), Johnson and Jensen (1998), Conover et al. (1999a, 1999b) use changes in discount rate implemented by the Fed to signal changes in the monetary policy and to further categorize monetary environments as either restrictive or expansive. An expansive (a restrictive) monetary environment is associated with the periods following discount rate decrease (increase). They find that average stock returns are higher (lower) in expansive (restrictive) monetary periods.

Although the findings in the studies cited above do not indicate the causality between discount rate and stock performance, the evidence that the stock price movement is associated with discount rate changes indeed offer investors a profitable investment strategy. For example, Conover et al. (1999a) examine the relationship between monetary conditions and global stock returns. Monetary conditions are measured by changes in both the local and the U.S. discount rate. They find that international stock returns are significantly related to both changes in local discount rate and changes in U.S. discount rate. By examining several investment strategies, they show that investors could improve the performance of their portfolios by using both U.S. and local monetary conditions to guide their portfolio allocations.

Conover et al. (2005) also use changes in the Fed discount rate to guide asset allocations. They demonstrate that an expansive monetary policy favors cyclical stocks whereas restrictive monetary policy benefits noncyclical stocks. Conover et al. (2008) investigate the efficiency of a sector rotation strategy that bases its asset shifts across U.S. equity sectors on changes in the discount rate. They conclude that the monetary policy is successful at guiding the sector rotation strategy, which outperforms a benchmark strategy as well as the market as a whole.

Recently, several hospitality research studies have examined the influence of macroeconomic factors on hospitality stock returns. Barrows and Naka (1994) argue that the identification of predictive ability of economic variables to stock price behavior in the industry sector would contribute to the industry analysis, and this would be true for the various hospitality sectors. They contribute to the hospitality literature by testing if U.S. hospitality stock returns are significantly related to economic variables, including changes in domestic consumption, money supply growth rate, term structure of the interest rate, growth rate of industrial production, and the expected inflation rate. They find that U.S. hospitality stock returns are significantly related to growth rates of money supply, changes in domestic consumption, and the expected inflation rate.

Chen et al. (2005) perform a similar examination. Industrial production growth, growth rate of money supply, expected inflation, changes in unemployment rate, and yield spread are five key economic variables used to summarize the state of the economy. They report that among those five factors, growth rate of money supply and changes in unemployment rate can best explain hotel stock returns in Taiwan.

Chen (2007c) expands the investigation of the impact of macroeconomic variables on hotel stock returns to the emerging Chinese stock market. He shows that industrial production growth rates, growth rates of imports, lag changes in discount rates, and changes in yield spread are significant economic explanatory factors of hotel stock returns in China. Similarly, changes in gross domestic product and industrial production are found to improve the stock performance of hospitality firms (Chen, 2007b).

Alternatively, Chen (2007a) examines the Taiwanese hotel stock performance under different monetary conditions and the impact of monetary policy changes on the association between Taiwanese hotel stock returns and economic variables. Note that Barrows and Naka (1994) and Chen et al. (2005) employ money supply growth rates as the monetary policy variable. Unlike the two studies above, Chen (2007a) argues that although a positive (negative) money supply growth rate is generally associated with an expansive (restrictive) monetary policy, frequent changes in money supply made it hard for the public to use money supply as a good indicator of different monetary policy regimes.

Chen (2007a) uses changes in the discount rate to detect monetary policy changes and examine hotel stock performance under different monetary conditions. Jensen and Johnson (1995), Jensen et al. (1996), and Conover et al. (1999a, 1999b) have shown that changes in the discount rate can classify the monetary environment as either restrictive or expansive. An expansive monetary environment is a period with a decrease in the discount rate and a restrictive monetary condition is a period with an increase in the discount rate. Empirical results show that under two monetary policy conditions, hotel stocks experience a higher mean return during expansive monetary policy periods. Moreover, the Sharpe and Treynor ratios of hotel stocks are positive and relatively high during expansive monetary periods, but negative in a restrictive monetary environment. The findings implied that even the risk-free asset outperforms the hotel stocks during the restrictive monetary condition. In addition, the link between hotel stock returns and economic factors varies greatly across monetary conditions.

Although the majority of past financial studies in the hospitality literature identify several critical economic and monetary explanatory factors of hospitality stock returns, these studies provide no specific rule or strategy for investments in hospitality stocks. This study differentiates itself from the previous work in two ways. First, a specific timing investment strategy that incorporates the monetary policy development measured by changes in the Fed discount rate is proposed. Second, the investment performance according to the proposed timing strategy is evaluated and compared with the buy-and-hold strategy using several risk-adjusted performance measures.

sec.title: Sample Data
sec.p: The proposed trading strategy uses discount rate changes to signal the timing to buy or sell hospitality sector stocks. The time series data of discount rate is needed to formulate an active timing strategy. Discount rate data are obtained from the website of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York (http://www.newyorkfed.org).

Four hospitality sector indices, risk-free (3-month T-bills) rate, and the market (S&P 500) index are obtained from the DataStream database. The four hospitality sectors are airline, hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure. The sample period covers about 35.5 years from January 2, 1973 to May 30, 2008. This long period of time enables us to establish a robust timing strategy and accurately evaluate the investment performance of the timing strategy. The daily index return (SR) is computed as SRt = ln(SPt / SPt−1) × 100% , where SP is the daily closing index for each hospitality sector or the market index. Table 1 presents descriptive statistics of daily index returns over the full sample period. For comparison purpose, we obtain different sector indices from the DataStream database over the same sample period and the statistics of daily returns of several industry indices also reported in Table 1.

fn.p: Note: The numbers in parentheses are the ranking among 19 sectors.

sec.p: As shown in Table 1, the mean daily return of airline, hotel, restaurant, travel and leisure, and S&P 500 indices over the full sample is 0.0097%, 0.0438%, 0.0401%, 0.0380%, and 0.0389%, respectively. The mean return of hotel and restaurant indices is greater than the mean market return. Among 19 sector indices, the hotel index has the third highest performance in terms of mean return. On the contrary, the performance of the airline index is the last.

However, the standard deviation of each hospitality index return is generally higher than that of the market index and other sector index returns. The standard deviations of the airline and hotel index returns are relatively high. When taking the risk into consideration and comparing the risk-adjusted performance, we find that the Sharpe ratio (mean excess return divided by the standard deviation) of hospitality indices is lower than that of the market index. In other words, the market portfolio is a better investment than hospitality sector stocks in terms of the return in excess of risk-free rate that an investor can obtain for bearing per unit of risk. This result also suggests that there is a need for hospitality stock investors to find a way to beat the market instead of buying and holding hospitality sector stocks.

sec.title: Timing Strategy Based on Discount Rate Changes
sec.p: To execute the timing strategy, we need to follow two steps. First, discount rate changes are used to signal shifts in monetary policy and characterize monetary environment as either expansive or restrictive (Conover et al., 1999a, 1999b; Conover et al., 2005; Jensen et al., 1996; Jensen & Johnson, 1995; Jensen & Mercer, 2006; Johnson & Jensen, 1998). An expansive monetary environment is a period with a fall in the Fed discount rate and a restrictive monetary environment experiences a rise in the Fed discount rate. Based on this classification scheme, the absolute level of the discount rate does not carry much significance. Rather, it is the direction of the last change that signals future monetary policy shift that matters. Thus, only the rate-change series is considered because the same monetary policy (expansive vs. restrictive) is assumed to be conducted by the Fed until a discount rate change in the opposite direction is observed. In other words, the monetary environment remains the same until the discount rate changes in the opposite direction. The period following a discount rate increase is classified as a restrictive environment; the period following a discount rate decrease is classified as an expansive environment. In consequence, according to this approach, the full sample period yields 19 rate-change series, 10 expansive monetary periods characterized by discount rate decreases, and 9 restrictive monetary periods characterized by discount rate increases (see Table 2).

caption.p: Series of Consecutive Discount Rate Increases and Decreases

sec.p: Second, shifts in monetary conditions are used to identify the timing to buy or sell hospitality sector stocks and T-bills. The timing trading strategy demands that investors hold hospitality sector stocks during expansive monetary periods and switch to T-bills during restrictive monetary periods. Accordingly, hospitality stock investors purchase the hospitality sector stocks on an initial discount rate drop and stay fully invested through all subsequent rate cuts. The timing strategy calls for a complete pullout from the investment in hospitality sector stocks on an initial discount rate increase and full investment in T-bills instead throughout the rate increase sequence.

The portfolio returns based on the timing strategy are calculated using the hospitality stock index returns for the expansive monetary policy periods and T-bills yields for the restrictive monetary policy periods. In comparison, the benchmark buy-and-hold strategy entails the purchase and holding of the market portfolio throughout the entire sample period. Return on the buy-and-hold strategy is equal to the market (S&P 500) return over the sample period. This study then compares the performance of the proposed timing trading strategy to that of a simple buy-and-hold strategy.

Following Conover et al. (2008), this study removes the first 2 days of every rate-change series from the sample to avoid any announcement period effect. The elimination of the announcement-period returns represents a conservative approach by minimizing the opportunity that investors may react and capitalize on the announcement of a change in monetary policy. Accordingly, there are 9,194 trading days during the sample period from January 2, 1973 to May 30, 2008: 5,042 trading days during the expansive monetary period, and 4,152 trading days during the restrictive monetary period.

sec.title: The Response of Sector Returns to Shifts in Monetary Regimes
sec.p: Prior to examining the timing evidence, a simple and preliminary analysis is performed to check if monetary policies, expansive versus restrictive, categorized by the direction of discount rate changes convey meaningful, “good” versus “bad” news for investments in the hospitality stocks.

Table 3 presents the mean return for all sector stocks and T-bills rate during the expansive and restrictive monetary conditions. For performance comparison and analysis purposes, all returns are annualized. As in Conover et al. (2008), daily returns are compounded by 250 (trading days) to obtain annualized returns. If discount rate changes serve as an effective measure for monetary environments and therefore as a good signal to buy or sell the hospitality sector stocks, we expect hospitality index returns during loosening monetary periods to be on average higher than those during tightening monetary periods. In contrast, T-bills should in general yield more under a restrictive policy than under an expansive policy.

fn.p: Note: The numbers in brackets are the ranking among 19 sectors.

sec.p: In addition, the difference in the mean return between the two monetary conditions can be used to assess the response of different sector indices to monetary environment measured by changes in the Fed discount rate. For example, if the difference in the mean return between the two monetary conditions is higher for the hotel sector than for the market sector, it suggests that the hotel index return has a stronger response to shifts in monetary regimes than the market return, that is, the hotel stock performance is more sensitive to monetary conditions than the overall stock market performance.

As shown in Table 3, airline, hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure indices have greater mean returns during expansive monetary periods than during restrictive periods. The difference in the mean return between the two monetary conditions is 7.96% for the airline index, 21.46% for the hotel index, 13.81% for the restaurant index, and 22.55% for the travel and leisure index. Among them, the difference in the mean return is statistically significant for the hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure sectors at the 5%, 10%, and 1% levels, respectively.

In contrast, the mean T-bills rate is lower during expansive monetary periods than during restrictive periods. The difference in mean over two different monetary conditions is statistically significant at the 1% level for T-bills. These findings illustrate that an expansive (a restrictive) monetary policy is good (bad) news for hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure sector stocks, but bad (good) news for T-bills.

Moreover, the difference in the mean return between the two monetary conditions is higher for the hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure sectors than for the overall market portfolio (S&P 500) and different sectors (except for automobile sector). In other words, hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure index returns are generally more sensitive to monetary conditions than the overall market index (S&P 500) return. Especially, travel and leisure and hotel sectors have the second and third highest difference in the mean return between the two monetary conditions among 20 sectors.

Table 4 presents the mean excess index return (index returns in excess of yield on T-bills) under two monetary regimes. Mean excess returns of hospitality indices are positive in the expansive monetary environment and negative in the restrictive monetary environment. Moreover, the difference in the mean excess index return is statistically significant for hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure sectors at the 5%, 10%, and 1% levels, respectively. These findings suggest that hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure sector stocks significantly outperform T-bills during expansive periods but underperform risk-free assets during restrictive monetary periods. Similarly, it is found that excess returns of hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure indices are generally more sensitive to monetary conditions than market excess return. Obviously, results reported in Tables 3 and 4 are in full conformity with the predicted assertion and lend support to the intuition of the proposed timing strategy for hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure sectors.

sec.title: Performance Measures and Evaluation Results
sec.p: Haugen (2001) states that any investment performance evaluation based on purely average historical returns would be biased because risks vary among portfolios and market strength shifts over time. In this study, the timing strategy involves holding risk-free securities for certain periods during which the resulting portfolio risk would be lower than that associated with the buy-and-hold strategy. Investment performance therefore needs to be evaluated by measures that can reflect and adjust for respective portfolio risk and market performance.

To examine the effectiveness of the timing strategy relative to the buy-and-hold strategy, this study uses several generally accepted performance evaluation methods. The first three risk-adjusted measures are conventional measures, including Sharpe ratio (Sharpe, 1966), Treynor’s measure (Treynor, 1965), and Jensen’s alpha (Jensen, 1968). In addition, GH measures, GH1 and GH2 (Graham & Harvey, 1997) and a two-beta regression model proposed by Merton (1981) are also adopted. Each of these performance measures is described below.

The timing strategy outperforms (underperforms) the passive buy-and-hold strategy on a risk-adjusted basis if Sharpe ratio is higher (lower) than that of the buy-and-hold portfolio.

Treynor’s measure is a reward-to-risk measure that shows the risk premium earned per unit of market risk. As illustrated in Equation (4), Treynor’s measure is calculated by dividing the average excess return of a portfolio by its market risk:

The beta of the buy-and-hold strategy (i.e., the market portfolio) is equal to 1. For the market-timing strategy, beta is estimated from the Jensen’s alpha regression model as given in Equation (5). The timing strategy is superior (inferior) to the passive buy-and-hold strategy if Treynor’s measure for the timing portfolio is greater (smaller) than that for the benchmark portfolio.

Jensen’s alpha, unlike the Sharpe ratio or Treynor’s measure, allows the statistical testing of the performance of a portfolio relative to the overall capital market. As expressed in Equation (5), Jensen’s alpha (α) is derived by regressing portfolio excess returns on market risk premium:

where Rp,t − Rf,t is the market timing portfolio’s risk premium at time t, α1 is the regression intercept term, that is, Jensen’s alpha, β1 is the beta or market risk of the market timing portfolio, Rm,t − Rf,t is the risk premium for the market portfolio and εt is the error term.

When α1 is positive and statistically significant, the timing portfolio has on average earned a higher return than the buy-and-hold portfolio. In other words, the timing strategy is preferred. Nonetheless, if α1 is negative and statistically significant, the passive buy-and-hold strategy is favored.

sec.title: Graham and Harvey’s Measures
sec.p: According to the capital asset pricing model (CAPM) of Lintner (1965) and Sharpe (1964), the systematic risk is the only risk for which investors should be compensated. Nonetheless, this does not change the fact that total risk or standard deviation is what investors bear and what matters in performance evaluation. Therefore, market risk–adjusted return measures such as Treynor’s measure and Jensen’s alpha do not necessarily identify the portfolio that provides the highest return for any given level of risk.

However, although Sharpe’s ratio reflects the risk premium earned per unit of total risk, the investment with the highest Sharpe ratio does not necessarily carry a risk desired by investors. To solve this problem, Graham and Harvey (1997) proposed two other risk-adjusted performance measures that allow a direct return comparison among investments and unambiguous identification of the optimal portfolio for any desired risk level. They show that their proposed measures are superior to the Sharpe ratio for performance evaluation purpose.

The difference between the two measures lies in the choice of the portfolio whose total risk is to be matched with. sec.title: Two-Beta Regression Model
sec.p: This study also adopts the two-beta (up-market beta and down-market beta) regression model of Merton (1981) and Henriksson and Merton (1981). The two-beta regression model accounts for the nonstationarity of systematic risk and allows for the separation of market timing ability from skills that are not related to market timing. In general, high-risk securities are more sensitive than low-risk securities to market movements. Thus, we expect skilled market timers to predict broad market movements and adjust their portfolios accordingly. On prediction of an up (a down) market, their portfolio compositions would be shifted to high-risk (low-risk) securities. sec.p: As shown in Panel A, without considering the timing strategy, the average of annualized airline, hotel, restaurant, travel and leisure, and market index returns are 2.45%, 11.58%, 10.54, 9.96%, and 10.20%, respectively. The corresponding standard deviations are 30.26%, 30.05%, 25.56%, 23.55%, and 15.81%. Panel B reports stock performance results based on the timing strategy. The average annual index returns of airline, hotel, restaurant, travel and leisure, and market sectors are 6.55%, 14.90%, 12.36%, 14.35%, and 11.95%, and the standard deviations are 23.05%, 21.62%, 17.25%, 16.36%, and 11.48%, respectively.1

The performance of the airline, hotel, restaurant, travel and leisure, and S&P indices improves in terms of higher mean returns and lower risk. Specifically, the mean of the airline, hotel, restaurant, travel and leisure, and S&P index returns increases by 4.10%, 3.32%, 1.82%, 4.39%, and 1.75% and risk is reduced by 7.21%, 8.43%, 8.31%, 7.19%, and 4.43%, respectively. Obviously, following the timing strategy, the increase in mean return and the reduction in risk are higher for the airline, hotel, restaurant, travel and leisure sectors than for the market portfolio.

In addition, the risk-adjusted performance following the timing strategy improves significantly. Both the Sharpe ratio and Treynor’s measure are more than twice the corresponding figures based on a strategy that simply buys and holds the corresponding sector stocks. Particularly, the Sharpe ratio and Treynor’s measure are more than three and four times the corresponding figures based on a buy-and-hold investment in travel and leisure stocks.

The risk-adjusted performance in terms of the Jensen’s alpha also indicates that the timing strategy outperforms a corresponding buy-and-hold investment in airline, hotel, restaurant, travel and leisure, and market indices. Furthermore, based on the Jensen’s alpha following the timing strategy, the performance of travel and leisure index is the best, following by hotel and restaurant indices, and all four hospitality indices outperform the S&P 500 market index.

Tables 6 to 8 present empirical results generated from the performance comparisons of the timing strategy with the buy-and-hold (market portfolio) strategy described in Section 4. Table 6 shows statistics generated from three risk-adjusted performance measures: the Sharpe ratio, Treynor’s measure, and Jensen’s alpha. For market portfolio and all hospitality sectors except airline, the timing strategy produces higher Sharpe ratio than the buy-and-hold strategy (panel A). Among all five sectors, the travel and leisure index has the highest Sharpe ratio, followed by S&P 500, hotel, restaurant, and airline indices. Similarly, the timing strategy produces generates a higher Treynor’s measure for hotel, restaurant, travel and leisure, and market sectors (panel B). The Treynor’s measures of travel and leisure, hotel, and restaurant indices are higher than that of market index: the travel and leisure index is first, following by hotel, restaurant, and S&P 500 indices.

sec.p: In panel C of Table 6, Jensen’s alpha is significantly positive for the market and three hospitality sectors except airline with a significantly negative alpha. The travel and leisure index has the highest value of alpha, followed by hotel, restaurant, S&P 500, and airline indices. It is noteworthy that the market beta is equal to 1, and the slope coefficient β lies between 0 and 1 for every hospitality sector; this is consistent with the expectation of lower risk for the timing portfolio than for the buy-and-hold portfolio. Moreover, both risk-adjusted measures of Graham and Harvey (1997) reported in Table 7 are positive for the market and all hospitality sectors. The travel and leisure index has the highest value of both Graham and Harvey measures, followed by hotel, restaurant, airline, and S&P 500 indices.

Table 8 summarizes the two-beta regression results. The effectiveness of the timing strategy is supported by the two-beta regression results for restaurant and travel and leisure sectors. As explained earlier, a positive and statistically significant β3 implies a successful portfolio risk escalation (reduction) in response to the market upturn (downturn) and provides evidence of superior market timing. As shown in Table 8, the coefficient β3 is significantly positive in hotel, restaurant, travel and leisure, and market sectors. However, β3 is positive but insignificant in airline sector.

In general, investors can follow the proposed timing strategy to improve the performance of investments in hospitality sector stocks by achieving higher returns, lower risk, and higher risk-adjusted performance. The outperformance of the timing strategy relative to the buy-and-hold strategy is supported by the Sharpe ratio, Treynor’s measure, Jensen’s alpha, and measures of Graham and Harvey (1997) in the hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure sectors. In other words, the superiority of the timing strategy over the buy-and-hold strategy is apparent in the hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure sectors. In addition, all five evaluation methods indicate that, based on the same timing strategy, investments in the hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure indices also outperform the market index.

sec.title: Subsample Analysis
sec.p: To examine whether the proposed timing strategy can consistently improve investments in the U.S. hospitality, we divide the full sample period from 1973 to 2008 into two subsample periods: 1973-1985 and 1986-2008, and perform the same analyses based on the timing strategy. The reason for the selection of these two subsample periods is that two subsample periods contain roughly an equal number of series of both discount rate increases and decreases. As shown in Table 2, each subsample period covers about five series of both discount rate increases and decreases.

The investment results with and without a timing strategy based on changes in discount rate are summarized in Table 9. During the period from 1973 to 1985, the risk-adjusted performance following the timing strategy (see panel B) is significantly higher than the corresponding figures based on a strategy that simply buys and holds the corresponding sector indices (panel A). All three risk-adjusted performance measures reveal that following the timing strategy, investments in hotel and travel and leisure indices outperform the S&P 500 index.

sec.p: Statistics generated from three traditional risk-adjusted performance measures are summarized in Table 10. For all hospitality sectors and market portfolio, the timing strategy outperforms the buy-and-hold strategy according to all three traditional risk-adjusted performance measures during the period from 1973 to 1985. All three risk-adjusted performance measures indicate that following the timing strategy, investments in hotel and travel and leisure indices outperform the S&P 500 index. In comparison, the timing strategy outperforms the buy-and-hold strategy in terms of all three traditional risk-adjusted performance measures in the market and travel and leisure sectors during the period from 1986 to 2008. During the same period, following the timing strategy, only investments in travel and leisure index outperform the S&P 500 index.

Both risk-adjusted measures of Graham and Harvey in Table 11 are positive for the market and all hospitality sectors during the period from 1973 to 1985. The hotel index has the highest value of both Graham and Harvey measures, followed by travel and leisure, airline, S&P 500, and restaurant indices. During the period from 1986 to 2008, both the Graham and Harvey measures are positive in airline, hotel, restaurant, travel and leisure, and market sectors. Both the Graham and Harvey measures are higher in travel and leisure and hotel than in the market sector.

The two-beta regression results are presented in Table 12. A positive and statistically significant β3 implies a successful portfolio risk escalation (reduction) in response to the market upturn (downturn) and provides evidence of superior market timing. During the period from 1973 to 1985, the coefficient β3 is significantly positive in hotel, travel and leisure, and market sectors, implying that the effectiveness of the timing strategy is supported for hotel, travel and leisure, and market sectors (see panel A). The effectiveness of the timing strategy is supported for restaurant, travel and leisure, and market sectors during the period from 1986 to 2008 (see panel B).

In summary, the timing strategy still outperforms a simple buy-and-hold investment in each hospitality index and market index over two subsample periods. The outperformance of the timing strategy relative to the buy-and-hold market portfolio strategy is also generally supported by five risk-adjusted measures in the hotel and travel and leisure sectors during the period from 1973 to 1985 and in the travel and leisure sector during the period from 1986 to 2008. Moreover, following the timing strategy, risk-adjusted measures illustrate that investments in the hotel and travel and leisure indices outperform the market index during the period from 1973 to 1985 and investments in the travel and leisure index outperform the market index during the period from1986 to 2008.

Moreover, Table 13 reports actual returns for both the passive buy-and-hold and the active timing approaches for the 19 subperiods. As shown in Table 13, for hotel and travel and leisure indices, the timing approach outperforms the buy-and-hold market portfolio in 15 of 19 (about 79%) subperiods analyzed whereas the timing approach beats the market in 14 of 19 (about 74%) subperiods for the restaurant index. In contrast, the active trading approach can outperform the buy-and-hold strategy only in 9 of 19 subperiods. These results have an important implication. As Tezel and McManus (2001) noted, “market timing is a popular active investment strategy that promises to beat the market.” The “timing” strategy proposed in the study does not imply that the results found for each hospitality sector are reproducible in each and every monetary policy regime in the entire sample period. In other words, the timing strategy certainly would not work in every time period. Even though the proposed timing strategy works well for the hotel and travel and leisure sectors, there are four subperiods when the market portfolio return is higher than returns on hotel and travel and leisure indices. However, empirical findings based on actual returns without a risk adjustment for 19 subperiods reveal that the strategy is still valuable as an alternative to buy-and-hold.

sec.title: Discussion and Conclusion
sec.p: Historical data over the 35-year time period from January 2, 1973 to May 30, 2008 show that the U.S. airline, hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure sector indices underperformed the market index (S&P 500) in terms of the Sharpe ratio. This result is consistent with the findings in Elgonemy (2000). He finds that the S&P 500 index outperformed the lodging stock during the period from 1995 to 2000. These findings suggest that simply buying and holding hospitality stocks is a poor investment strategy. It is necessary for hospitality stock investors to find a method of improving their investments in the U.S. hospitality sector stocks.

This study provides investors with a timing strategy for investments in U.S. hospitality sector stocks according to shifts in the Fed monetary policy. Changes in the discount rate are used to measure the Fed monetary policy shifts and characterize the full monetary policy period as either an expansive or a restrictive monetary policy environment. An expansive monetary condition is a period with a decrease in the discount rate; a restrictive monetary environment is a period with an increase in the discount rate. The study illustrates that directional changes in the Fed discount rate can signal when to buy or sell hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure sector stocks. Following the timing trading strategy, investors purchase and remain fully invested in hospitality sector stocks during expansive monetary policy periods and sell hospitality sector stocks and invest fully in T-bills when the discount rate reverses its direction and starts to increase.

Johnson and Jensen (1998) argue that many timing strategies do not appeal to the majority of investors because the methods are complicated and require a constant monitoring of the indicators under consideration. In contrast, the timing strategy proposed in the study has several advantages.

First, it is easy to follow. Laurent (1988) states that changes in the discount rate can be viewed as exogenous signals of the Fed actions and these signals are easy for the public to interpret. Moreover, directional shifts in discount rate are simply binary (i.e., increase or decrease) and are therefore easy to identify.

Second, it does not require frequent trading and trading costs are relatively low. Changes in the Fed discount rate are relatively infrequent. The timing strategy trades only 18 times over the 35-year study period (i.e., one transaction is made every 2 years, on average). Thus, transaction costs are not a significant factor in implementing the timing strategy based on the directional shifts in the Fed discount rate (Conover et al., 1999a; Conover, Jensen, & Johnson, 2002; Johnson & Jensen, 1998; Prather & Bertin, 1998).

Third, there is no “look-ahead bias.” Conover et al. (2008) argue that discount rate changes can be identified on an ex ante basis and thus contain no “look-ahead bias.” In contrast, some strategies are contingent on indicators that can be identified ex post. For example, financial investment textbooks generally suggest investing in cyclical industries (industries with high sensitivity to the state of the economy) during periods of economic expansion and switching investments to defensive industries (industries with low sensitivity to the state of the economy) during periods of economic contraction. However, the textbooks fail to demonstrate how to time these decisions since the business cycle is usually identified ex post only.

Indeed, the empirical evidence from the U.S. hospitality industry in this study provides a good example of how to implement timing investment decisions based on a proxy of changes in business cycle as proposed by investment textbooks. Directional shifts in the Fed discount rate can be used as the proxy of changes in business cycle. As mentioned, the Fed monetary policy can affect the economy by regulating interest rates. Numerous empirical studies have supported a strong link between economic conditions and monetary policy environments. Hence, shifts in Fed monetary policy can signal the future direction of the economy (i.e., expansion and contraction of the business cycle). Whereas the business cycle can be only identified ex post, changes in the discount rate can be identified on an ex ante basis. Furthermore, directional shifts in the discount rate are easy for the public or market participants to detect and interpret.

As a result, periods with a decrease in the discount rate (an expansive monetary condition) are associated with the expansion of the business cycle, whereas periods with an increase in the discount rate (a restrictive monetary condition) are associated with the contraction of the business cycle. By examining the historical monthly data over the same time period, this study confirms that there is a significant association between discount rate changes and changes in business cycle (taken from the National Bureau of Economic Research website, http://www.nber.org/) although the link may not be absolutely perfect. The correlation coefficient between the two factors is 0.34 with a significance level of 1%.

Moreover, portfolio performance based on the timing strategy is evaluated with various risk-adjusted performance measures. Empirical evidence derived from the daily trading data over a 35-year time period generates three major findings. First, the risk-adjusted performance of investments in hospitality sector indices following the timing strategy improves significantly relative to a passive buy-and-hold strategy.

Second, all five risk-adjusted performance measures support the superiority of the proposed timing strategy for investments in hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure indices over the buy-and-hold market portfolio strategy. Third, following the timing strategy, investments in the hotel, restaurant, and travel and leisure indices also generally outperform the market index in terms of all five risk-adjusted performance measures.

Among four hospitality sectors, the timing strategy cannot beat the market portfolio only in the airline sector. There are several possible explanations for this result. Arndt and Zellner (2003) attribute the success of airline companies mainly to their hedging fuel strategy and lower operating costs. Zea (2003) argues that hedging is a common way for airlines to manage the financial risk of input price changes, and no airline input is more volatile than fuel. He reports that the Cathay Pacific Airways was one of the major airlines that sustained a large loss in operating profit because of the increase in fuel price in 2000. This may suggest that fluctuations in fuel prices, not changes in the discount rate, have a more significant influence on the airline sector.

The results of subsample analyses still reveal that the timing strategy outperforms a passive buy-and-hold investment in each hospitality index during both subsample periods. All five risk-adjusted performance measures demonstrate the superiority of the proposed timing strategy over the buy-and-hold market portfolio strategy in the hotel and travel and leisure sectors during the period from 1973 to 1985 and in the travel and leisure sector during the period from 1986 to 2008. Furthermore, following the timing strategy, investments in the hotel and travel and leisure indices outperform the market index during the period from 1973 to 1985 and investments in the travel and leisure index outperform the market index during the period from 1986 to 2008. In addition, even without a risk adjustment, actual returns from discount rate change trading for hotel and travel and leisure indices exceed those of the passive buy-and-hold market portfolio in 15 of 19 subperiods classified based on different monetary policy regimes.

The findings in this study have a practical implication for the individual and institutional investors. For investment purposes, even though hospitality stocks have a lower risk-adjusted performance (Sharpe ratio) than the market, market participants or investors would still invest in hospitality sector stocks because of the diversification that they bring to an investment portfolio. In addition, investments in an index/mutual fund with an industry focus, for example, Abacus Hospitality Fund 2 and HEI Hospitality Fund III3 have been a popular and low-cost way for small investors to pursue a passive investment strategy in the hospitality sector.

This study offers both individual investors and fund managers a valuable timing strategy for investments in U.S. hospitality sector stocks instead of a passive buy-and-hold strategy. As Tezel and McManus (2001) noted, the lack of strong results in support of the market-timing ability may be due to the fact that few mutual funds managers specialize in market timing. This study shows that a simple indicator of directional changes in the Fed discount rate could have been used for individual investors and fund managers to improve the investment performance over the 35-year time period under consideration.
